content:
AUTHORITY FOR 16- AND 17-YEAR-OLDS TO LOAD MATERIALS INTO SCRAP PAPER BALERS AND PAPER BOX COMPACTORS. Section 13(c) of the Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that are safe and cannot be operated while being loaded. The Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938 is amended to allow 16- and 17-year-old employees to load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards and cannot be operated while being loaded. Employees aged 16 and 17 can load materials into scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards set by the American National Standards Institute. Employees aged 16 and 17 can operate scrap paper balers and paper box compactors that meet safety standards certified by the Secretary to be protective of minors. The machines must have an on-off switch controlled by employees aged 18 or older, kept off when not in use. Employees aged 16 and 17 can operate scrap paper balers and paper box compactors certified to be safe for minors. The machines must have an on-off switch controlled by employees aged 18 or older, kept off when not in use, with a notice posted on the machines. Employees aged 16 and 17 can operate scrap paper balers and paper box compactors certified to be safe for minors, with specific guidelines in place. Employees aged 16 and 17 can only load scrap paper balers and paper box compactors, while those under 18 are prohibited from operating or unloading them. The Secretary will publish safety standards for these machines, and employers must report any injuries to employees under 18. Employers must report any injuries to employees under 18 resulting from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. Employers must report injuries requiring medical treatment or resulting in fatalities of employees under 18 from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors. The reports are used by the Secretary to assess the safety impact of safety measures. The reports required by employers for injuries or fatalities involving employees under 18 from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors include details such as employer and employee information, incident date, and place of employment. These reports are used by the Secretary to evaluate the effectiveness of safety measures. The reports required for injuries or fatalities involving employees under 18 from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors must include employer and employee details, incident date, injury description, and equipment information. The reports for injuries or fatalities involving employees under 18 from contact with scrap paper balers or paper box compactors must include incident date, injury description, and equipment details such as manufacturer and model number. Reports should be submitted to the Secretary within 10 days of the incident, and cannot be the sole basis for determining violations of safety regulations. The Secretary must receive reports on injuries or deaths within 10 days of the incident. These reports cannot be the only basis for determining violations of safety regulations. Reporting requirements expire 2 years after enactment. SEC. 2. Civil money penalty amended for Fair Labor Standards Act of 1938. Section 16(e) is updated to include penalties for violations of section 12 or section 13(c)(5).

SEC. 3. Construction clarification for exemption of apprentices and student learners in section 570.63 of title 29, Code of Federal Regulations. Section 1 does not affect the exemption for apprentices and student learners in section 570.63 of title 29, Code of Federal Regulations.
